definition: to change/to become different/to transform/to vary/rebellion

sentences.english: Their colleagues in an army battalion stationed in Wuchang mutinied.
sentences.chinese: 他們在武漢軍營中共事的同事發動了這次叛變。

sentences.english: Jalloud is the third top defection reported in a week.
sentences.chinese: 據報導，賈盧德是一星期內第三位叛變的高級官員。

sentences.english: In a few companies, interviewing for a new job is considered tantamount to treason.
sentences.chinese: 少數公司認爲在職員工面試其他工作等於叛變。

sentences.english: Old money has confirmed asvaghosa mutiny, his comrades life organization quickly evacuated.
sentences.chinese: 老錢已經確認馬鳴叛變，他命組織上同志們迅速撤離。

sentences.english: At this period, a lot of pupils of evil knife fortress unexpectedly and suddenly appalled.
sentences.chinese: 這時，魔刀堡的很多弟子竟然突然叛變了。

sentences.english: To declare that the New Fourth Army has "mutinied" and cancel its official designation.
sentences.chinese: 宣佈新四軍“叛變”，取消該軍番號。

sentences.english: The officer deserted to the enemy.
While being debriefed the defector named two double agents .
sentences.chinese: 在詢問過程中叛變者供出了兩名雙重間諜。

sentences.english: The extreme right wing mutinied just before the election.
sentences.chinese: 極右派在大選前夕叛變。

sentences.english: His traitorous activity got him court-martialed.
sentences.chinese: 他的叛變活動使他受到軍法審判。

sentences.english: It was reported that some of the king's troops had revolted.
sentences.chinese: 據說有些王室軍隊已經叛變。

sentences.english: Almost all scholars didn' t notice Liu Shipei' s psychology after he betrayed revolution.
sentences.chinese: 劉師培叛變革命後有無愧疚心理，學界沒有提及。

sentences.english: The Liberal Democrats' high command denied that he was thinking of defecting.
sentences.chinese: 自民黨最高指揮部否認肯尼迪考慮叛變的消息。

sentences.english: But kato department can also be a mutiny, kato army suffered losses.
sentences.chinese: 不料加藤部將沙也可叛變，令加藤軍遭受損失。

sentences.english: Three sailors were fomenting a mutiny on the ship.
sentences.chinese: 三個水手正在船上煽動叛變。

sentences.english: You think that Nicolai would prefer treachery?
sentences.chinese: 你認爲尼科萊會贊成叛變嗎？

definition: Chen Jiongming (1878-1933), a leading warlord of Guangdong faction, defeated in 1925 and fled to Hong Kong
to forfeit sovereignty and humiliate the country (idiom)/to surrender territory under humiliating terms
mutiny/(Tw) to be dumped by one's girlfriend while serving in the army
the Kempeitai or Japanese Military Police 1881-1945 (Japanese counterpart of the Gestapo during WWII)
Autumn Harvest Uprising (1927), insurrection in Hunan and Jiangxi provinces led by Mao Zedong
to denounce/to condemn/to call to account/to punish
to rise in revolt/to raise difficult questions
